instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.LCD_BKLT_PWM: What is LCD_BKLT_PWM? LCD_BKLT_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Hi. I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no backlight with 12.5 volts on pins 21 & 22 of J9000. After changing <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> I still have 12.5 volts on output. Thanks for any help in advance.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Hi. Thank you for the responses. FB is 12.5, <RESISTOR>R0910</RESISTOR> is 12.5 pin 1&2, BKL EN is 3.1 and 0 PWM is 0. Thanks.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Check <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR>, do you have any voltage on <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL>??

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> comes from PCH, check this line on diode mode.....

[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Im sorry. I have .58 on  <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> from via.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: I'm assuming PCH is at fault and nothing else can be done. Ended up running a wire from <CAPACITOR>C9711</CAPACITOR>.  Thank you very much for your help.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Now having a more problems related to BKLT after running wire. every 10 -15 seconds durring OS install the screen will go to sleep and I will have to press the power button to wake it up. Any thoughts?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Your issue was never with the PCH or backlight circuit. Your PWM is missing because it think's it's sleeping. Try a new Magsafe board as that has the sleep sensor on it.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: The sleep sensor is on the battrery light indicator....  Remove the BIL and check is <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is high......

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> issue. So either the battery indicator or the pull up resistor on this line <RESISTOR>R5071</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Holy Shit! Hahaha... I'm such an asshole! Here I am dicking around trouble shooting a logic board, when the whole time it was the Batt Indicator as you guys pointed out. I pulled one from another machine and everything is up and running. What a dildo. Thank you Aprendiz, TCR and Duke. Much appreciated. Have a good one!
